CoSMoS

  • Quickstart CoSMoS
  • View page source

Quickstart CoSMoS¶

To setup CoSMoS for your area of interest, you can generally follow these steps:

Step 1: Install CoSMoS

Install CoSMoS on your device.

Step 2: Make a local copy the CoSMoS run folder.

Copy the default folders cosmos_run_folder and model_database from your CoSMoS installation folder to the folder where you want to run CoSMoS.

Step 3: Add models to the model database.

Add wave and/or flow models for your domain of interest.

Step 4: Adjust your model executable paths.

In the configuration folder, you can find the file *config.toml*. Adjust the model executable paths (for the models that you want to be running) to your local installations. Also, make sure to link to the correct model_database folder.

Step 5: Setup a scenario file.

Setup a scenario file in which you describe which models of your model database you want to run, for which period, and with which metereological data. For a first CoSMoS run, choose one of the meteoreological data options listed in the default meteo_subsets file (see Meteo). You can also add the NOAA-COOPS tide station file (see Observation stations) to your scenario file to compare observed and computed water levels.

Step 6: Run CoSMoS.

Once you have completed Step 1 to 5, you can execute a first CoSMoS run. The output is stored in the scenario folder, and you can view the results of your run in the webviewer (see Output)

Advanced CoSMoS configurations:¶

Step 7: Add observation data.

In addition to the regular NOAA-COOPS tide stations, for which water level data is downloaded automatically from a server, you can manually add observation station locations and data.

Step 8: Add meteoreological data.

There are several options to manually include meteorological data to force your model(s) (see Meteo). You can generate your own regularly gridded meteorological forcing or include a spiderweb file. Alternatively, you can create an ensemble of cyclone tracks to obtain a probabilistic hazard prediction.

Step 9: Organize your models in a super region file.

If you have created a large database of models and want to include them efficiently in your scenario file, you can organize the models in a super region file (see Super regions). Instead of calling all models in the scenario file, you now call this super region file.
